required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Hypochlorous Acid Disinfection Prior to Cataract Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Hypochlorous Acid Disinfection on Ocular Flora Prior to Cataract Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: Antibiotics are commonly utilized to reduce the bacterial population of the eye prior to surgery with the assumption that this reduces the risk of endophthalmitis, although it is not clear if this actually occurs. This study will investigate the use of Hypochlorous Acid, a commercially available over the counter (OTC) medication to see if this will reduce the bacterial population prior the cataract surgery.

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction in bacterial flora in eyelashes of treatment eye compared to fellow eye
primary_outcome.time_frame: On day of surgery prior to surgical prep
primary_outcome.description: Swab will be used to obtain samples from the eyelashes bilaterally and cultured

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction in bacterial flora in conjunctiva of treatment eye compared to fellow
primary_outcome.time_frame: On day of surgery prior to surgical prep
primary_outcome.description: Swab will be used to obtain samples from the conjunctiva bilaterally and cultured

intervention.description: 0.02% Hypochlorous Acid Gel (OCusoft Hypochlor GEL) will be sprayed onto the closed eyelid of the surgical eye while covering the fellow eye with palm of the hand, left for 60 seconds, then wiped off with a clean gauze, tissue, or cotton ball.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoing cataract surgery.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age <18 years old
- Vulnerable subjects
- Non-English Speakers

overall_official.affiliation: Loma Linda University Department of Ophthalmology
